title: Request account visibility
body:
Android 8 adds some limitations on account visibility for apps which target SDK level 26+.
In particular an app no longer sees available accounts until it has been granted a certain "visibility" on that account.
As a result, OpenTasks now removes task lists, even though the account they belong to still exists.

Sync apps should call [setAccountVisibility](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/accounts/AccountManager#setAccountVisibility(android.accounts.Account,%20java.lang.String,%20int)) for every account they wish to sync to OpenTasks.

We need to decide whether OpenTasks should also ask the user for access to that account. The problem is that we'll have to do that for every account which no longer exists because we won't be able to distinguish between accounts "invisible" to OpenTasks and accounts that don't exist without tracking the accounts we have been granted access to.

title: Determine publishing track by version number format
body:
The idea is to determine the right track from the git version description.
In general we have three different cases:

* 1.1.14-1-g0b73bd7b-dirty

  A dirty working tree goes the to the internal channel. That's not something that should be published to any user

* 1.1.14-1-g0b73bd7b

  An untagged commit goes to the alpha channel.

* 1.1.14

  A tagged commit goes to the beta channel. From where it can be published as a release.

We never publish directly to the release channel.

title: Fix wrong ID being used. Fixes #723
body:
In an earlier commit we changed how the lists are loaded. Instead of loading them from the tasks table we now load them from the instances table. This was meant to prepare support for recurring tasks.

Unfortunately we missed on line where we were still using the `_id` column to get the task id (when we should actually use the `task_id` column now). This didn't cause any problem as long as the task id and the instance id where in sync (hence it wasn't an issue while testing). However, under certain circumstances this assumption is no longer true and caused an illegal Task URI to be loaded when clicking a task.

The list now uses the `task_id` column to create the task URI to show.

title: Zero counts clutter the interface
body:
The "Tasks starting" tab in v. 1.1.13 has entries for "Already started", "Today" "Tomorrow", "Someday" and "Later".  

* Tasks which have no start day are not shown neither under "Someday" nor under "Later".  Please chech, whether the number behind "Someday" is calculated correctly.

* Chronologically it makes more sense to put "Later" (if it means defined start) before "Someday" (meaning without clear start).  Consider switching the two entries.

* If all tasks have no starting day and are therefore shown all under "Someday" consider hiding the whole "Tasks starting" tab, as this only clutters the interface in this case.

* Likewise for "Tasks due" - it shows correctly everything under "Someday", but if all entries are under "Someday" then the "Tasks due" tab can be hidden in order not to clutter the interface.

* Likewise, if all tasks have "no priority", or have the same priority, consider hiding the  "Task priority" tab.

* When the setting "Show completed tasks" is selected, the "Tasks due"  and "Tasks priority" tab do not include the completed tasks.

* In the "Task progress" tab, the "Done" section shall not be shown, when "Show completet tasks" is not selected, because it is supposed always to contain zero elements and thus clutters unnecessary the interface.

title: Split recurring tasks when modifying the first instance
label: [Label(name="provider")]
body:
It's probably a good idea to split a recurring tasks when overriding the first instance. After the split there would be a single task for the override and a recurring task starting at the next instance (if there is any). This way we don't have to deal with all the old instances of completed tasks. Also some clients seem to support this model only (i.e. Apple clients).
The drawback is, we loose the information about the recurrence, i.e. the current instance would appear as a single task, not a recurring one. One solution to this could be to add a special relation which identifies this task as a part of a recurrence set.

title: "Compress" recurring master tasks
label: [Label(name="provider")]
body:
We should make sure we always store the most compact version of a recurring tasks. For instance
- if an `RDATE` doubles an instance generated by an `RRULE` we can remove the `RDATE`
- if an `RDATE` is cancelled out by an `EXDATE`s we can remove them both (given the previous rule had already been applied)
- if an `EXDATE` doesn't cover any existing instance generated by an `RRULE` or specified by an `RDATE`, we can remove it
- if an `EXDATE` covers the first instance generated by an `RRULE`, we can remove the `EXDATE` and move `DTSTART` to the next instance generated by that rule (unless the instance had been moved as a result of a `SKIP` parameter).
- if an `EXDATE` covers the last instance generated by an `RRULE`, we can remove the `EXDATE` and let the `RRULE` end at the previous instance

Before upgrading to target SDK Level 26 we need to figure out a way to handle these changes (probably even before doing so). We only need to read the accounts in order to remove orphaned lists when an account has been removed or a sync app has been uninstalled.

The later case could be handled by checking if there are authenticators for every account in the lists table. That won't solve the account removal case though.

If I understand the changes correctly a sync app could give OpenTasks access by default and OpenTasks would be able to get the accounts without asking the user. If a sync app doesn't do that, the lists might either be removed frequently (like in #404) or lists of removed accounts would not be removed automatically.

`IS_UPCOMING` instance column
label: [Label(name="provider")]
body:
In #566 we'll implement expansion of recurring tasks and in #567 we'll also handle overrides. A a result the instance table will be populated with one entry for every instance of a recurring task. This would be very impractical for certain views in the UI. Pretty much every view that we currently have is supposed to show the next relevant instance of a task, otherwise the list might be crowded with all the instances of few recurring tasks. In order to solve this we need an instance column which identifies upcoming or future instances (i.e. everything after the next incomplete instance). For efficiency and simplicity this should be determined at the end of a batch. The value should only be updated if necessary, i.e. if 
* an override has been created or deleted
* the status of an override or the master has been changed
* any datetime or recurrence value of the master or an override have been modified

Note for non-recurring tasks `IS_UPCOMING` is always false. If we make this the default position, we don't need to (re-) calculate this column for non-recurring tasks.

When I add an item to an existing checklist by pressing the "+ Add Item" button, text entry in the new box works as normal until I enter the first space character. The insertion point can be manually moved after it resets to work around the issue, but it makes it hard to enter any items with spaces, especially when working fast.  

I can reproduce this on two different phones. Of note this does not appear to happen when making a new checklist, only when editing an existing one to add items.

title: Show subtasks on details view. #442
body:
This is far from finalized but I submit it now to get the discussion going.

Questions, notes:

Will using `Tasks.PARENT_ID` be okay for the subtask query?

UI: How should the subtask list look like? Same view repeated, with only the first having the icon, but same spaces between them as with other task details? Or should subtasks be listed within a 'frame' with maybe less vertical gap between them? Use some actual frame lines?
(Current state is just a quick initial setup, not intended to stay like this)

About the loading using RxJava2, I guess there can be many questions there, please check the code and let me know.

I haven't given much thought about packaging the new classes yet, so that's left as well.

Important thing about the loading: currently it is started in `onLoadFinished()` because when it was in `onCreateView()`, the view items didn't show up after loading the screen the second time. Not sure what that was, maybe it's only because `SubtaskView` currently adds the items to a `LinearLayout` and calls `requestLayout()` after it, all within a `ScrollView`, so maybe if that happens before the original content is loaded, then it doesn't work for some reason.

Please check the loading multiple times, it varies greatly for me, sometimes immediate, sometimes delayed compared to the original content.
So unfortunately this multiple loading does add some uncertainty here. As I mentioned before, I think one approach could be to do one loading, so zip/merge the 2 flows together and deliver the results once. That requires to 'Rxify' those loading, if we used Rx for the zip.

A little bit related that compared to current state where loading is handled in the fragment, I think it could actually be nicer to have a custom view for the subtasks (/properties) part that handles loading on its own, when let's say `update(mTaskUri)` is callled on it. But this would mean separate loading.

Please feel free to also comment on specifics already even though it is in initial state.

title: Inexact alarms scheduled by AlarmManager.set()
body: By the way, I also found `AlarmManager.set` is used to schedule a timeout in [NotificationActionUtils](https://github.com/dmfs/opentasks/blob/6d5db7bc045e4a74cedbea4461719637714a4897/opentasks/src/main/java/org/dmfs/tasks/notification/NotificationActionUtils.java#L326). For your reference, the behaviour of this API is changed since API 19, afterwards, the alarms scheduled by this API will be treated as inexact. ([doc](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/AlarmManager.html#set(int,%20long,%20android.app.PendingIntent))). After API 19, setExact will schedule the alarm at the exact time.

title: Deprecation of android.text.format.Time
label: [Label(name="maintenance")]
body:
Hi,
I found that class android.text.format.Time is used in many places in open tasks (like [NotificationActionUtils](https://github.com/dmfs/opentasks/blob/6d5db7bc045e4a74cedbea4461719637714a4897/opentasks/src/main/java/org/dmfs/tasks/notification/NotificationActionUtils.java#398), [NotificationUpdaterService](https://github.com/dmfs/opentasks/blob/6d5db7bc045e4a74cedbea4461719637714a4897/opentasks/src/main/java/org/dmfs/tasks/notification/NotificationUpdaterService.java#L588), [TimeRangeCursorFactory](https://github.com/dmfs/opentasks/blob/7eb211a910cd607bb04e93ab9270813c38e9bc9a/opentasks/src/main/java/org/dmfs/tasks/groupings/cursorloaders/TimeRangeCursorFactory.java#L117) and many other places). This class has been deprecated since API since API 22 due to many known issues, including 2038 problem, timezone problem etc. (details in the [doc](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/text/format/Time.html)) As suggested by the doc, [GregorianCalendar](https://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/GregorianCalendar.html) will be a good alternative for Time.

title: Extended Undo
label: [Label(name="Epic")]
body:
At present we only allow undoing very few actions. The majority of all actions is irrevocable (at least as far as it concerns the OpenTasks UI). This Epic will introduce an Undo option for more operations. It should be possible to undo pretty much every operation which modified the database.

The basic idea is to use OpenTasksPal when working with the provider. Every time an operation is created and committed a matching "undo operation" is created and stored in a stack (along with a label that describes the operation). That is, when committing an Operation which sets a task to completed, another operation is created which restores status and percent complete and wipes the completed date.
Executing the undo operations from the top of the stack will restore the previous database state.

The undo stack is limited to a specific number of entries and will be cleared whenever the app is closed. So it doesn't need to be persisted.

If an action can not be undone (like when deleting a local list) the undo stack is cleared.

Handling of async changes from other apps (like sync apps) still needs to be defined. I.e. how can we prevent an "undelete" of a task if the list it belongs to has just been deleted by the sync adapter?

when I open the 'Tasks' app, tasks and task lists are almost always gone. Waiting for a while or hitting 'Refresh' from the menu brings them back. 1. Manually close Tasks app (or do not use it for quite a while) - i.e., make sure it's not running in the background.
2. Open Tasks app -> No tasks and no calendar names are shown.
3. Hit 'Refresh' (or wait for a long while)
4. Calendar names come back
5. Wait some longer: tasks reappear

- Android version: 7.1.2
- LineageOS version: 14.1-20170918-NIGHTLY-athene
- OpenTasks version: 1.1.9 (installed via F-Droid)

title: Give more information about affected task if validation fails
body:
@korelstar commented on [Mon Aug 22 2016](https://github.com/dmfs/opentasks-provider/issues/8)

`TaskValidatorProcessor` throws an `IllegalArgumentException` if a task does not comply with all constraints. However, sometimes it is not possible to reproduce which task is affected. Therefore, it would be nice, if the exception's message would contain some information in order to identify the affected task, i.e., it's title.

Background and motivation: if there are tasks on a server with `DUE < START` (yes, that is not allowed but some server do not enforce this) and these tasks should be synchronized using e.g. DAVdroid with OpenTasks. Now, the user gets the error message `DUE must not be < DTSTART` but is not able to find out which tasks are affected, without complicated and time-consuming debugging. Extending the exception's message with the task title would be very helpful in order to quickly correct the wrong data on the server.

See also this discussion: https://forums.bitfire.at/topic/1178/more-details-on-error-due-must-not-be-dtstart

title: feature Request: Alternate CalDav-Description Rendering
body:
Background: I am using OpenTasks, Davdroid on Android and Thunderbird with Lightning on my Desktop to sync with a Davical-Server.

Most Clients Render the Description of a Tasks as plain text which does not result in a usable Task-Overview especially if the task is more complex. Using OpenTasks with other Clients results in strange plain_text e.g.. OpenTasks uses [ ] and [x] for checkboxes but if one line of the description text contains [ ] OpenTasks will add a [ ] to all following lines so its not possible to to something like:

"my nice description of the task. Do Following:
[ ] text1
[ ] text2
[ ] text 3
and dont forget to do:
[ ] text
[ ] text"

Would it not be a good idea to expect the description field to contain markdown and parse markdown to a UI (e.g. html on client side with [marked](https://github.com/chjj/marked)) with this approach it is more compatible between clients.

Features needed summarized:
- Add a markdown editor to modify the Task description --> replace description and checkbox field
- Convert markdown client-side to UI e.g. as html
(- additionally it would be nice to weight "checkboxes" e.g.
      -[ ]{1} Write this request  -> default
      -[ ]{8} Implement Features
so you can calculate the overall progress with weights.)

Looking forward to a controversy. If the request is excepted I am willing to develop a Thunderbird-lightning add-on so support markdown ( Does not make sense for me atm if there is no android client which supports this feature.)

title: New constraints and defaults (forbid DUE=START)
body:
- [x] `CustomizedDefaultFieldAdapter`: Introduce customizable default values (new interface `Default`) in order to provide different defaults for `DUE` (should be after `START`: new class `DefaultAfter`) and `START` (should be before `DUE`: new class `DefaultBefore`).
- [x] New constraint `After`: requires that a value is *after* another value (e.g. `DUE` must be after `START`); if constraint is violated, set value to the default (`DefaultAfter`); similar to the old `NotBefore`.
- [x] New constraint `BeforeOrShiftTime`: requires that a value is *before* another value (e.g. `START` must be before `DUE`); if constraint is violated, then the reference value (e.g. `DUE`) is shifted with respect to the duration of the task.

With the two new constraints, we prohibit `DUE=START` and therefore fix #262. The constraint `BeforeOrShiftTime` is a tradeoff between shifting always (cp. constraint `ShiftTime`) and shifting never (cp. constraint `NotAfter`); maybe this is sufficient in order to close #197.

title: Remove Flicker and Scroll-to-Top in Widget
body:
Sometimes, when the widget is reloaded (e.g. due to a background sync of tasks with DavDroid), the widget flickers and scrolls to the top of the list, which is very annoying. The cause of this is the reset of `mItems` to `null` at the begin of the `reload()` in combination with an external refresh of the widget. However, setting `mItems` to `null` is not required, since the background runnable sets the new value, when loading is finished.

Therefore, I removed this `null` reset which fixes the mentioned issue.

title: Widget: order by START date/time if DUE and PRIORITY are indistinguishable
body:
Currently, the widget order is as follows:
1. by `DUE` (early due first, no due last)
2. by `PRIORITY` (high priority first, no priority last)
3. by `CREATED` (new tasks first)

In order to have a better control of tasks with the same (or no) `DUE` and `PRIORITY`, I propose to add a new condition `START` after `PRIORITY`:
1. by `DUE` (early due first, no due last)
2. by `PRIORITY` (high priority first, no priority last)
3. by `START` (early start first, no start last)
4. by `CREATED` (new tasks first)

Then, already started tasks are listed before tasks which haven't been started yet, and tasks which have been started a long time ago come before recently started tasks. This helps the user to keep the number of active tasks low in order to concentrate on finishing already started tasks. Furthermore, it allows to influence the order of tasks without `DUE` more fine-grained than using priorities.

title: Offer settings to minimalise options in interface
body:
Personally, I like all the feature but some elderly friends of mine and friends with concentration challenges find the interface offering too many options and are visually overloaded. This distracts them and they have a hard time using this otherwise very good app.

Please consider adding the following options which are off by default and are called:
1. Show check list
2. Show dates (and times)
3. Show detailed progress
4. Show privacy

For each item, I would like to provide a rational that also applies to normal users.
1. The "Show check list" will show checklist related controls and info. Not many people use this, so it might be hidden as default, making the app more lighter in use and not bother people with these options if they do not use them. This should also hide/show Tasks due tab.
2. The "Show dates and times" or shorter "Show dates" will show all date and time related controls and info for start, end and due date and all day and time zone. I know this is supported in VTODO, but some people should be encouraged to use their calendar for date and time related events so it is stored in a VEVENT. See also https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Getting_Things_Done (What could be offered is a feature to convert a task into a calendar appointment by adding date and time and delete it as a task. Thunderbird offers this for example. For that another feature request should be created.) Hiding and showing thesecontrls and info shoudl also be reflected in the Tasks due and Tasks starting tab.
3. The "Show detailed progress" or "Show progress details" shows completed date time and percent completed as is now. But when switched off, only shows if a task is completed or not. Simple and what most users probably need.  Hiding and showing these contrls and info should also be reflected in the Tasks progress tab.
4. On "Show privacy"; privacy is usually covered by the url and credentials of the calendar service being used. Controls and info for this can be hidden by default as well as not many users use this and is only confusing to novice users.

Implementing these features will greatly simplify and improve the user experience for those who do never use certain aspects and/or are easily distracted with too many functions.

title: FR: Change priority without having to open the editor
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Users who make extensive use of priorities may find it annoying that changing a priority takes so many steps (open task, edit task, scroll down, tap priority, select priority, save).

At this time I see 3 options:
1. Allow changing the priority in the details view with a single click and automatically commit changes. This may require some redesign of the details view, also it requires that the priority field is always visible, even for tasks that don't have any priority value
2. Allow to move tasks to a different priority group by using drag'n'drop in the priority tab, the major challenge here is adding drag'n'drop support to the expandable list view
3. Change the "fling functions" in the priority tab to "increase priority" and "reduce priority" rather than "edit" and "complete"

Any other options?

title: Features request
body:
Hi,

I have some suggestions for this great piece of app, if you are interested :)

1 - I use tasks everyday, and to be honest I think there are too much options while creating a task : in my case, but I'm sure I'm not the only one :), I enter the task's name and have to scroll down to set the due date (I have 1280x720 display). I don't use anything else, or rarely.

Could it be possible to have a basic mode when creating the task, with just the name, the due date, the location for example, and eventually a box to hit to expand the advanced mode and access the remaining options ? I think it can not be a general configuration option, as it depends of the task and the needs of the user for each one.

2 - Is it possible to create an event in a specified calendar when creating a task with a start and a due dates ? Or maybe it is already happening, I never checked.

3 - In the widget, could it be possible to have an option to sort the tasks by lists ? I personally prefer the current behavior, but a friend suggested it.

4 - In the task creation/modification screen, I really dislike the current calendar (with the 3 wheels for month/day/year) as I need to scroll again and again... I would prefer a classical one, a small window showing the traditional calendar and allowing me to just "click" the day I want. For me, it is faster and easier to visualize (the time/distance between two days, the remaining weeks before the due date, etc). As I know many people like the wheels, could it be an option ?

5 - In the widget, but it depends of the display's resolution and size, is it possible to add a validation button for each task ? The same size than the "+" for example ? Because every time I want to set one as finished, it opens the app, I click the button, it backs to an other task (still on the app) and I have to use the back button of Android to return to the widget. So I know the widget is not intended to replace the app, but some small functions like this would speed up my "workflow" xD

title: Task lists doubled after system crash
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
First of all: Thanks for the great app! :+1: 
## Prologue

A few days ago, my Nexus 4 with Android 5.1 rebootet automatically into Safe Mode. After another reboot to get back to normal operations, all my custom (non-Google) accounts and widgets were gone (including CalDAV account to sync my calendar and task list). It seems that Safe Mode deletes 3rd party widgets and accounts rather than deactivating them while in Safe Mode.

According to the thread [Accounts/widgets lost in safe mode](http://forum.xda-developers.com/showthread.php?t=2364444) on the XDA Forums, this is a known bug (at least I'm not the only one). And this problem is easy to solve: Just re-add the accounts and the widgets and everything is restored.
## The actual problem

Before restoring it, I noticed that all the tasks are still in the Tasks app (contrary to the calendar events).

After restoring the accounts, I checked this and all task lists in the app are doubly present (even in the activity **Synchronized Lists**). Hence, all tasks are listed twice, too (in every view). Even if I deactivate (unselect) **all** lists, the _old_ tasks are still listed (only the first view, where all tasks are grouped by list, is empty).

I thought this is a caching problem and get solved after a while, but the old tasks are still visible (and editable). I even pressed a few times `reload` and restartet my Nexus.
## Side note

While readding my caldav account, I selected new and different colors. But I don't think, this is relevant.

title: Hide date and time functionality for GTD
body:
For people who are using Getting Things Done (GTD) time management method, see
also https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Getting_Things_Done, this app very good. However, when using tasks in GTD, these never have a start or due date. Those are destined to be calendar events. I know this is part of the VTODO in iCalendar format and all apps working with it should support it.

If people are never using this, it would be good to have a general option to hide all data functionality in the GUI. It will make the GUI more easy to use and (new) people using GTD will not be tempted to use
dates in tasks while they should actually create calendar events for this. Thirdly, it will make creating tasks faster because you don't need to scroll past the fields for dates to get to the priority setting etc.

See screenshot feature-request-show-date-functionality-GTD.png how it would look if this feature request is implemented. This general setting would also show/hide the DUE and START tabs.

If Tasks is GTD-friendly that could lead to positive publicity in the GTD-community (which is not so pleased with tasks offered by Google, Evernote, etc. that allow deviating from their method) and increase the
number of people using Tasks.

![feature-request-show-date-functionality-gtd](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/198964/4374493/a6fe4864-4334-11e4-9fc9-fd6489ad5a60.png)

title: Feature request: Pin task as notification
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
**1st use case:** Shopping list.

I'm going to visit a grocery store, so I write down a task with many checkboxes (awsome feature!). But when I switch to other app this task gets lost somewhere in the list of many other tasks.

I would like to have checkbox to "pin" the task as notification, just like when its alarm goes off, but with slightly different icon (but that is not important).

This way I could keep the shopping list task easily available during my visit in the store.

**2nd use case:** To keep track of what I'm doing right now. Let's say I need to buy a tickets after visiting the grocery store (from previous use case) and then do some other things on different places. Traveling will take some time and it is easy to forget something. So before I go I would pin all the tasks for that particular trip to keep them in sight. I did that few times already with non-permanent calendar notifications and it is very handy.

You may ask why not to use 'Today' view for this. Well, pinned notifications allow you to select only relevant tasks for now and do not mix them with other things you need to do today, for example when you get back to office after the running around the town.

Thank you! :)
